notes: Igbo consonants include some sounds not found in English, such as gb, kp, and gw
Extensive consonant variation exists across Igbo dialects, with 19 interchange patterns documented:
- Major interchanges: L/R, F/P, S/T (common across dialects)
- Fricative variations: F/H/SH, R/H, R/SH, S/SH, Y/H (fricative shifts)
- Plosive variations: B/V, B/W, G/V (plosive-fricative shifts)
- Complex patterns: N/L/Y (nasal-liquid-palatal), F/V, R/F (multiple pathways)
- Approximant shifts: Y/GH, W/GH (palatal and velar)
- Nasal mergers: NY/Ṅ, NW/Ṅ (palatal and labialized nasals)
IMPORTANT: Many shifts are context-dependent and phonologically conditioned
- Consonants marked with 'context_dependent: true' have shifts that occur in specific environments
- Example: H in R/H is NOT the same as H in Y/H or F/H/SH - these are different phonological contexts
- These shifts are NOT freely interchangeable for word creation
- The listed shifts represent observed dialectal variations, not productive alternations
These variations are documented in the Ndebe orthography system
The Ndebe script provides distinct symbols for each variant to maintain clarity
Some consonants like 'gb' and 'kp' are doubly-articulated labial-velar sounds
The dotted consonants (ṅ) represent specific phonetic values distinct from their undotted counterparts
